facts.text: Sahib Singh Mehra published an article in his paper Kaliyug of Aligarh dated September 12, 1960 under the heading Ultra Chor Kotwal Ko Dante.

anchor.surface_text: Sahib Singh Mehra, appellant in this appeal by special leave, published an article in his paper Kaliyug of Aligarh, dated September 12, 1960, under the heading Ultra Chor Kotwal Ko Dante which means that a thief reprimanded the kotwal, a police officer, though the right thing would be the other way.

facts.text: The article contained expressions about justice standing as a helpless spectator while illicit bribe money from plaintiffs and defendants enters pockets of public prosecutors and assistant public prosecutors.

anchor.surface_text: The article companytained the following expressions, as translated How the justice stands at a distance as a helpless spectator of the show as to the manner in which the illicit bribe money from plaintiffs and defendants enters into the pockets of public prosecutors and assistant public prosecutors and the extent to which it reaches and to which use it is put.

facts.text: Public Prosecutor and eleven Assistant Public Prosecutors at Aligarh requested Superintendent of Police for sanction to file complaint under s. 500 I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: The Public Prosecutor and the eleven Assistant Public Prosecutors at Aligarh requested the Superintendent of Police for obtaining the sanction of the Government for filing a companyplaint by the District Government Counsel in the Court of the Sessions Judge under s. 500 I.P.C.

facts.text: Home Secretary, U.P. Government wrote to Inspector General, U.P. on March 1, 1961 conveying sanction under section 198B Cr.P.C. for filing complaint under s. 500 IPC against Editor and Publisher of Kaliyug for defamatory article dated September 12, 1960 against Asst. PP Sri R.K. Sharma and other police prosecuting staff.

anchor.surface_text: The Government was duly approached through proper channel and, ultimately, the Home Secretary, U.P. Government, wrote to the Inspector General, U.P. on March 1, 1961 I am directed to companyvey the sanction of the State Government under section 198B c  of the Code of Criminal Procedure to the filing of a companyplaint under section 500 Indian Penal Code in a Court of Sessions, against the Editor and Publisher of the Newspaper Kaliyug of District Aligarh which published a news item under the caption Ulta Chor Kotwal Ko Dante in its issue, dated September 12, 1960 companytaining defamatory remarks against the Assistant Public Prosecutor Sri R. K. Sharma of District Aligarh and other police prosecuting staff of the Government in respect of their companyduct in the discharge of public functions.

facts.text: Public Prosecutor of Aligarh filed complaint in Court of Session, Aligarh for offence under s. 500 I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Public Prosecutor of Aligarh filed the companyplaint in the Court of Session, Aligarh, praying for the summoning of the accused and for his trial according to law for the offence under s. 500 I.P.C.

facts.text: Appellant admitted before Sessions Judge the publication of the impugned article, stated no evil intention, published for public good in general terms.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant admitted before the Sessions Judge the publi- cation of the impugned article and stated that he never had any evil intention. He further stated that he had published the news item for the good of the public and that he had published it in most general terms to bring bad things to the numberice of the Government and the authorities for the public good.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted appellant under s. 500 IPC, sentenced to simple imprisonment for six months and fine of Rs. 200.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge companyvicted him of the offence under s. 500 P.C. holding that the aforesaid statements in the article were defamatory and that the appellant was number protected by exceptions 3 and 9 to s. 499 I.P.C. He sentenced the appellant to simple imprisonment for six months and a fine of Rs. 200.

facts.text: Appeal against conviction dismissed by Allahabad High Court on January 29, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 47 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated January 29, 1963 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 998 of 1962.

facts.text: Appellant published something defamatory of R.K. Sharma in May 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant published sometime in May 1960 something which was defamatory of R. K. Sharma.

facts.text: R.K. Sharma filed a complaint about earlier publication in September 1960.

anchor.surface_text: R. K. Sharma filed a companyplaint about it in September 1960.

facts.text: Public Prosecutor in complaint restricted to defamation of R.K. Sharma and other police prosecuting staff at Aligarh.

anchor.surface_text: The Public Prosecutor, however, in his companyplaint, restricted it to the defamation of R. K. Sharma and other police prosecuting staff of the P. Government at Aligarh.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We dismiss the appeal.

facts.text: Sanction was for defamation of R.K. Sharma and other police prosecuting staff of Government of Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The sanction referred to above, in this case, and companyveyed by the Home Secretary to the Inspector-General of Police, was a sanction for making a companyplaint under S. 500 P.C. against the appellant with respect to the article under the heading Ulta Chor Kotwal Ko Dante, in the issue of Kaliyug dated September 12, 1960, companytaining defamatory remarks against the Assistant Public Prosecutor, R. K. Sharma, of Aligarh, and other prosecuting staff of the Government in respect of their companyduct in the discharge of public functions.

arguments.claim: Explanation 2 provides that it may amount to defamation to make an imputation concerning a company or an association or collection of persons as such... The prosecuting staff of Aligarh... is certainly such an identifiable group or collection of persons

anchor.surface_text: Section 499 I.P.C. defines defamation and provides inter alia that whoever makes or publishes any imputation concerning any person intending to harm, or knowing or having reason to believe that such imputation will harm, the reputation of such person, is said, except in cases covered by the exceptions to the Section, to, defame that person. Explanation 2 provides that it may amount to defamation to make an imputation concerning a company or an association or collection of persons as such.

arguments.claim: The impugned remarks are per se defamatory of the group of persons referred to

anchor.surface_text: We have not been referred to any case relating to S. 499 P.C. in support of the contention for the appellant that the Public Prosecutor and Assistant Public Prosecutors at Aligarh could not form such a body of persons as would be covered by Explanation 2 to S. 499 I.P.C. The impugned remarks are per se defamatory of the group of persons referred to.

arguments.claim: they are not corrupt, and according to their knowledge, none at Aligarh, is corrupt in the discharge of his duty

anchor.surface_text: In this case, the Public Prosecutor and Assistant Public Prosecutor had deposed that they are not corrupt, and according to their knowledge, none at Aligarh, is corrupt in the discharge of his duty.

arguments.court_reasoning: No evidence to contrary; supports presumption of reputation

arguments.claim: Exception 3 to s. 499 I.P.C. comes into play when some defamatory remark is made in good faith... Exception 9 gives protection to imputations made in good faith for the protection of the interest... or for the public good

anchor.surface_text: Exception 3 to s. 499 I.P.C. comes into play when some defamatory remark is made in good faith. Nothing has been brought on the record to establish that those defamatory remarks were made by the appellant after due care and attention and so, in good faith. Exception 9 gives protection to imputations made in good faith for the protection of the interest of the person making it or of any other person or for the public good.

arguments.claim: the sentence is severe and be reduced to the period of imprisonment already undergone

anchor.surface_text: It is urged for the appellant that the sentence is severe and be reduced to the period of imprisonment already undergone.

arguments.court_reasoning: No justification; press responsibility requires deterrent sentence for reckless comments with ulterior motive

arguments.claim: persons responsible for publishing anything in newspapers should take good care before publishing anything which tends to harm the reputation of a person. Reckless comments are to be avoided. When one is proved to have made defamatory comments with an ulterior motive and without the least justification motivated by self-interest, he deserves a deterrent sentence

anchor.surface_text: We do not see any justification for reducing the sentence. The Press has great power in impressing the minds of the people and it is essential that persons responsible for publishing anything in newspapers should take good care before publishing anything which tends to harm the reputation of a person.

holdings.text: The sanction granted under section 198B Cr.P.C. was specific to the defamatory remarks against Assistant Public Prosecutor R.K. Sharma and other police prosecuting staff, and did not suffer from any defect.

anchor.surface_text: The sanction referred to above, in this case, and conveyed by the Home Secretary to the Inspector-General of Police, was a sanction for making a complaint under S. 500 P.C. against the appellant with respect to the article under the heading Ulta Chor Kotwal Ko Dante, in the issue of Kaliyug dated September 12, 1960, containing defamatory remarks against the Assistant Public Prosecutor, R. K. Sharma, of Aligarh, and other prosecuting staff of the Government in respect of their conduct in the discharge of public functions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sanction explicitly references the article, R.K. Sharma, and other prosecuting staff; Public Prosecutor could restrict complaint to Aligarh staff; form complies with s.198B(3).

holdings.text: Prosecuting staff at Aligarh constitutes an identifiable collection of persons that can be defamed under Explanation 2 to s.499 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Section 499 I.P.C. defines defamation and provides inter alia that whoever makes or publishes any imputation concerning any person intending to harm, or knowing or having reason to believe that such imputation will harm, the reputation of such person, is said, except in cases covered by the exceptions to the Section, to, defame that person. Explanation 2 provides that it may amount to defamation to make an imputation concerning a company or an association or collection of persons as such.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanation 2 covers identifiable collections distinguishable from community; Aligarh staff is definite group within UP prosecuting staff.

holdings.text: It is not essential for an offence under s.500 IPC that the defamed person be an individual; a collection of persons such as prosecuting staff can be defamed.

anchor.surface_text: The next question to determine is whether it is essential for the purpose of an offence under S. 500 I.P.C. that the person defamed must be an individual and that the prosecuting staff at Aligarh or, as a matter of fact,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.499 defines defamation of 'person' including per Expl.2 company, association or collection if identifiable.

holdings.text: The impugned remarks are per se defamatory of the group of Public Prosecutor and Assistant Public Prosecutors at Aligarh.

anchor.surface_text: We have not been referred to any case relating to S. 499 P.C. in support of the contention for the appellant that the Public Prosecutor and Assistant Public Prosecutors at Aligarh could not form such a body of persons as would be covered by Explanation 2 to S. 499 I.P.C. The impugned remarks are per se defamatory of the group of persons referred to.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Remarks impute corruption (bribe-taking); no authority supports exclusion of such group; per se harms reputation.

holdings.text: Intention to harm reputation of particular Public Prosecutors or Assistant Public Prosecutors is proved by publication of imputations concerning identifiable group.

anchor.surface_text: Section 499 I.P.C. defines defamation and provides inter alia that whoever makes or publishes any imputation concerning any person intending to harm, or knowing or having reason to believe that such imputation will harm, the reputation of such person, is said, except in cases covered by the exceptions to the Section, to, defame that person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Publication of imputation concerning identifiable persons satisfies mens rea under s.499.

holdings.text: Prosecution need not prove the defamed group had reputation that could be harmed; presumption of good reputation holds unless disproved.

anchor.surface_text: Unless proved otherwise, the presumption is that every person has a good reputation. In this case, the Public Prosecutor and Assistant Public Prosecutor had deposed that they are not corrupt, and according to their knowledge, none at Aligarh, is corrupt in the discharge of his duty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption of good reputation; prosecutors testified to lack of corruption, no contrary evidence.

holdings.text: Exceptions 3 and 9 to s.499 IPC do not protect the appellant; remarks not made in good faith or for public good.

anchor.surface_text: Exception 3 to s. 499 I.P.C. comes into play when some defamatory remark is made in good faith. Nothing has been brought on the record to establish that those defamatory remarks were made by the appellant after due care and attention and so, in good faith. Exception 9 gives protection to imputations made in good faith for the protection of the interest of the person making it or of any other person or for the public good.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of due care; ulterior motive to deter proceedings by R.K. Sharma; not for public good.

holdings.text: Appellant rightly convicted of offence under s.500 IPC by defaming Public Prosecutor and Assistant Public Prosecutors at Aligarh.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the appellant has been rightly held to have committed the offence under s. 500 P.C. by defaming the Public Prosecutor and Assistant Public Prosecutors at Aligarh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All elements satisfied: identifiable group defamed per se, no exceptions apply, sanction valid.

holdings.text: No justification to reduce sentence; deterrent sentence deserved for reckless defamatory comments with ulterior motive.

anchor.surface_text: We do not see any justification for reducing the sentence. The Press has great power in impressing the minds of the people and it is essential that persons responsible for publishing anything in newspapers should take good care before publishing anything which tends to harm the reputation of a person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Press responsibility requires deterrence for unprivileged defamation motivated by self-interest.

anchor.surface_text: We dismiss the appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; conviction under s. 500 IPC upheld; no reduction in sentence granted

anchor.surface_text: The sanction referred to above, in this case, and conveyed by the Home Secretary to the Inspector-General of Police, was a sanction for making a complaint under S. 500 P.C. against the appellant with respect to the article under the heading Ulta Chor Kotwal Ko Dante, in the issue of Kaliyug dated September 12, 1960, containing defamatory remarks against the Assistant Public Prosecutor, R. K. Sharma, of Aligarh, and other prosecuting staff of the Government in respect of their conduct in the discharge of public functions.
We dismiss the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Section 499 I.P.C. defines defamation and provides inter alia that whoever makes or publishes any imputation concerning any person intending to harm, or knowing or having reason to believe that such imputation will harm, the reputation of such person, is said, except in cases covered by the exceptions to the Section, to, defame that person. Explanation 2 provides that it may amount to defamation to make an imputation concerning a company or an association or collection of persons as such.
We dismiss the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We have not been referred to any case relating to S. 499 P.C. in support of the contention for the appellant that the Public Prosecutor and Assistant Public Prosecutors at Aligarh could not form such a body of persons as would be covered by Explanation 2 to S. 499 I.P.C. The impugned remarks are per se defamatory of the group of persons referred to.
We dismiss the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Section 499 I.P.C. defines defamation and provides inter alia that whoever makes or publishes any imputation concerning any person intending to harm, or knowing or having reason to believe that such imputation will harm, the reputation of such person, is said, except in cases covered by the exceptions to the Section, to, defame that person.
We dismiss the appeal.

edges.explanation: Holding h6 on presumption of good reputation unless disproved supports concept c14 that such remarks harm reputation unless proved otherwise.
Holding h6 that prosecution need not prove reputation harm due to presumption addresses issue i5 on whether prosecution led evidence to establish defamed group had reputation that could be harmed.

anchor.surface_text: Unless proved otherwise, the presumption is that every person has a good reputation. In this case, the Public Prosecutor and Assistant Public Prosecutor had deposed that they are not corrupt, and according to their knowledge, none at Aligarh, is corrupt in the discharge of his duty.
We dismiss the appeal.

edges.explanation: h7 holds exceptions to s.499 do not apply as remarks not for public good, addressing i6 on whether remarks were for public good

anchor.surface_text: Exception 3 to s. 499 I.P.C. comes into play when some defamatory remark is made in good faith. Nothing has been brought on the record to establish that those defamatory remarks were made by the appellant after due care and attention and so, in good faith. Exception 9 gives protection to imputations made in good faith for the protection of the interest of the person making it or of any other person or for the public good.
We dismiss the appeal.
We dismiss the appeal.
We dismiss the appeal.
